member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.HighlightingItemBase
member.summary: Base class for all LC objects that can be highlighted.

remarks.para: Highlighting style can be controlled through mouseHighlight property.
Reading of the current highlighting state can be read using IsHighlighted() method.
This also makes it possible for the user to manually control forced highlighting of the object.
Presents HighlightedStateChanged event that notifies changes in the objects highlighted state.
Currently changing object visibility and/or highlight mode might not cause event to fire. This is a known problem.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.ChartNode.GetChartFromOwner(System.Object,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Retrieves chart. Uses cached value (should be correct if owner is set) unless IterateToTop is set to true, in which case it climbs all the way through parent chain to the LC.
member.remarks: Chart is updated when parent is set, thus there is no way the different ways should result in different value. Implemented the cached value retrieval later (same as calling IChartNodeInt.Chart) later and left the old stuff just to make sure.
member.param: itme to get the parent for.
If false, uses cached value (should always be correct). If true climbs through the parent chain.

member.summary: Helper method for disposal of the given DrawData. Set the reference to null.
member.remarks: Intentionally not checking validity of the device or chart reference. It's left to caller, so that we do not have to do the checks on each call. Might not be the proper place for this, but this is common ancestor to just about everything, and has the chart reference.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.IHighlightingItem
member.summary:
Interface of objects that can be highlighted.
Allows user to highlight the object and define how the object should be highlighted. The objects also report to users when they are highlighted.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.IHighlightingItem.SetHighlight
member.summary:
Highlights the object.
This is a kind of "forced" highlight, and the object might be highlighted even if the highlighting type (defined by MouseHighlight property) is set to None. How the highlighting happens, if any, depends on object. Most objects use the defined type by default, and fall back to Simple highlighting if None is set.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.IHighlightingItem.RemoveHighlight
member.remarks: Note that this does not prevent the highlighting caused by mouse hovering.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.IHighlightingItem.IsHighlighted
member.summary: returns true if the object is highlighted.

remarks.para: Note that this value reflects the state of the object before it's drawn on screen, so if mouse is moved, this is set, and then a new frame is drawn. Prior version 8.0.1 returned value reflected the currently visible state, meaning that the state changed only after the new frame, and thus right after mouse hoveiring the state was kind of wrong.

member.returns: True if the object is highlighted.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.IHighlightingItem.MouseHighlight
member.remarks: Note that forced highlighting does not necessarilly follow this. See SetHighlight for more information.

member.name: E:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.IHighlightingItem.HighlightedStateChanged
member.summary: Event telling that highlighted state has changed. Contains information of the new state.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.IHighlightingItemInt
member.summary:
Internal interface for the items inheriting IHighlightingItem. Note that there is nothing forcing the inheriting, but both of these should be inherited. We trust it internally.
Allows deliver of the mouse over / off information that allows us to determine if the object is to be highlighted or not.
Also makes it possible for the system to cause the emitting of the notification events.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.IHighlightingItemInt.InvokeHighlightedStateChangedEvent(Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.HighlightStateSource)
member.returns: True emitting of the event succeeds. If no event listeners is registerd, this should return true.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.IHighlightingItemInt.SetHoover(System.Boolean)
member.summary:
System for notifying the object that the object has been selected through hoovering.
Call this every time the object is selected as active obect, and with false before new object is selected.
member.param: If true, the object knows it's the currently active object using mouse.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.IHighlightingItemInt.SetInternalHL(System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Used to HL item internally, through legend box etc.
Similar to thte SetHighlighting / RemoveHighlighting, but reports different source to client, and does not change the user set state.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.HighlightingItemBase.m_mouseHighlight
member.summary: Defines the type the object is supposed to be highlighted. Set through public interface properties / DP.
member.remarks: By setting this to be property we could react to it and emit event on change. Currently we emit it only on forced change / mouse over changes. Not if visibility or highlight type changes.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.HighlightingItemBase.m_bIsDrawnHighlighted
member.summary: Obsolete variable that was used before this system was implemented in V8.0.1. The highlighting was determined on drawtime, and this was set there. Now this is not needed, or used otherwise than to detect the situations where the old draw-time detemination differs from pre-draw determined value. This can be used to find places that has not yet been modified to the new system.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.HighlightingItemBase.m_bForceHighlight
member.summary: Defines if the user has requested the item to be highlighted throug SetHighlight / RemoveHighlight methods.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.HighlightingItemBase.m_bInternalHL
member.summary:
Status of internal highlighting - not through hovering.
For instance legend box hover uses this to hl items.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.HighlightingItemBase.SetHighlight
member.summary:
Highlights the object.
This is a kind of "forced" highlight, and the object might be highlighted even if the highlighting type (defined by MouseHighlight property) is set to None. How the highlighting happens, if any, depends on object. Most objects use the defined type by default, and fall back to Simple highlighting if None is set.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.HighlightingItemBase.RemoveHighlight
member.remarks: Note that this does not prevent the highlighting caused by mouse hovering.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.HighlightingItemBase.IsHighlighted
member.summary: returns true if the object is highlighted.

remarks.para: Note that this value reflects the state of the object before it's drawn on screen, so if mouse is moved, this is set, and then a new frame is drawn. Prior version 8.0.1 returned value reflected the currently visible state, meaning that the state changed only after the new frame, and thus right after mouse hoveiring the state was kind of wrong.
For object to be highlighted, it needs to be visible, and mouse must be in top of it, highlighting must be set manually, or the item must be highlighted by hovering over legend box.

member.returns: True if the object is highlighted.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.HighlightingItemBase.Arction#Wpf#BindableCharting#IHighlightingItemInt#InvokeHighlightedStateChangedEvent(Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.HighlightStateSource)
member.param: Arguments to use instead of current objects stored MouseEvent arguments. Can be used to speed up speed up the call if the event is already constructed.
member.returns:
Return value of the Charts RaiseEvent method. False if the event could not be emitted, true otherwise.
True emitting of the event succeeds. If no event listeners is registerd, this should return true.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.HighlightingItemBase.InvokeHighlightedStateChangedEvent(Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.HighlightStateSource)
member.param: Arguments to use instead of current objects stored MouseEvent arguments. Can be used to speed up speed up the call if the event is already constructed. Note that the object is not updated in any way if given, so it can be used to deliver wrong information.
member.returns:
Return value of the Charts RaiseEvent method. False if the event could not be emitted, true otherwise.
True emitting of the event succeeds. If no event listeners is registerd, this should return true.

member.summary: Gets or sets anchor. This is a dependency property. Rotation uses this point as a center point. Tells where to place the anchored point within the control area. For X dimension, value 0 represents left coordinate of the object and 1 right coordinate. For Y dimension, value 0 represents top coordinate of the object and 1 bottom coordinate. To define anchor point outside the object area, define values outside range 0...1.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.NormImg(System.Double)
member.summary: Normalize the absolute imaginary axis value. Means z(d) => r+jx, where ImgR(z(d)) = j(X/Z0).
member.remarks: See http://care.iitd.ac.in/People/Faculty/bspanwar/crl713/smith_chart_basics.pdf page 145.
member.param: Absolute imaginary axis value to normalize to -1..1 range.
member.returns: Normalized imaginary axis value, in range -1..1. Values can be larger, of course, but then they reside outside the unit circle.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.NormReal(System.Double)
member.summary: Normalize the absolute real axis value. Means z(d) => r+jx, where RealR(z(d)) = R/Z0.

remarks.para: No reason to keep NormReal and NormImg separate, except that not sure if there will be changes later.
See http://care.iitd.ac.in/People/Faculty/bspanwar/crl713/smith_chart_basics.pdf page 145.

member.param: Absolute real axis value to normalize.
member.returns: Normalized real axis value. Normalized to range 0..1. Values outside this range do not fit in the Unit circle.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.AbsImg(System.Double)
member.summary: Convert the normalized imaginary value to absolute scale.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.NormValueToUCValue(Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.PointSmith)
member.summary: Converts normed smith value value pair to UC coordinates

remarks.para: The real and imaginary values are normed values of the RealValue and ImgValue axis. Circle radiuses mathing those values area calculated, the intersection point of the circles area calculated in normed unit-circle space, and then returned. The other intersection point of the circles is at point 1,0 (in UC space), the Y-component of the RealValue circle center point is 0 (center is at X-Axis), and the X-component of the Imaginary circle is 1. See http://mathworld.wolfram.com/Circle-CircleIntersection.html.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.UCValueToNormedValue(Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.PointFloat)
member.summary: Convert normed coordinates in unit circle space (Origo at the center of the circle) to matching normed real and imaginary values.
member.returns: PointFloat with Normed RealValue (on X-parameter) and Imaginary (on Y-parameter) components, matching the given coordinates.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.GridType
member.summary: Defines how the grid is defined. If the value is Distance, GridDivSpacing property will affect the positioning and amount of gridlines. Otherwise GridDivCount will be used in calculations. This is a dependency property.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.GridDivSpacing
member.summary: Approximate distance between gridlines in pixels. Used only if GridType is GridTypeSmith.Distance. This is a dependency property.
member.remarks:
The final distance between gridline positions is not precisely the requested distance, but the requested distance is only taken as starting point, and a value is then search from around that point that can be presented as a nice looking string.
Current reference value has a small effect on the gridline positions, as itll affect on what are the nice values we end up putting the gridlines to.
It should also be noted that each Real gridline has matching Imaginary gridline. At certain parts of the chart the imaginary gridlines are naturally more close to each other than the real gridlines, and thus have more effect on the positioning of the gridlines than the real gridlines.
By setting AutoFormatLabels property to false, SupplyCustomImgString and SupplyCustomRealString events can be used to redefine the label string for the gridlines.
GridReal and GridImg properties GridOptionsSmith.CustomGridLines property can be used To place custom gridlines on the view.stomGridLines property can be used To place custom gridlines on the view.

Ignore zeros values from logarithmic axis fitting
member.remarks: For logarithmic axis, call Fit method with pixel range, for appropriate behaviour.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Axes.AxisY.CalculateAxisWidth(Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Views.ViewXY.AxisLayout,Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LightningChartUltimate.delegateMeasureString,System.Double@)
member.summary: Calculates the width of the axis box and the base line division. If Division is 0, all of the width is on right side of the axis line center, if it's 1, all of the width is on left side. Thus width of the left side from the axis line is width * Division and right is width * (1-Division).
member.param: Views Axislayout to be applied with the calculation. Required for the YAxisAutoAlign and YAxisTitleAutoPositioning proeprties.
Factor of how much of the width is on left side of the axis centerline.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.IBGListener
member.summary: Interface for objects that listen for settings updates from ISettings objects. This is part of a demo to test how to separate settings from actual UI objects.
member.remarks:
The IUiSettings object is seen and handled by user, and shareable by multiple different parents (it has no parent bindings, or has many).
It is however bound to multiple of these, and these will in turn contain the cached stuff of the object, and are able to draw themselves and cache the drawdata.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.IBGListener.SettingsChanged(Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.IUiSettings)
member.summary: Method to call from the Settings object (IUiSettings) to notify that the settings has been changed and thus the cached object must become dirty.
member.param: Settings object whose settings has changed.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.BGListenerNode
member.summary: Base implementation of the IBGListerner, with ChartNode. This is part of a demo to test how to separate settings from actual UI objects. The idea is that this can be used as object that holds cached data - DD and settings - of the drawable objects.
member.para: As this is ChartNode, this object is part of the Parent-Child relationship of the chart.

DD usage:
DD's can be set as dirty by SetDirty() or SettingsChanged() methods. These methods do not necessarilly dispose or clear the DD, as some operations might be able to reuse the old DD. Setting objec dirty will cause the DD's to be updated on next drawing.
Disposing the DD's can be done using FreeDrawData() call. Use this when engine changes or DD's need to be cleared for some other reason.

Drawing:
Object can be drawn by calling the Draw() method. If the object is dirty, the DD is created first. The engien given on call might not be used on DD creation, as some DD creation methods might fetch the engine from the view/chart. The engine paremeter might be removed later.

Inheriting: Implement the following methods:
FreeDrawData - Must be implemented. Dispose all DD's and null references. BecameDirty - Called when the object becomes dirty for some reason. If there is no need to react to that, it needs not to be implemented. The Dirtynes is internally stored and Draw() method can check that on calls and generate DD at that time. Draw - Needs to be

Interfaces:
IBGListener: the main interface that defines the listener functionality of this class.
IDDContainer: Allows cleaning and later possibly drawing of the DD's

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.IUiSettings
member.summary: Interface for UI side Settings objects. Objects inheriting this interface are inteded to be the ones that users see and can interact with and think as the actual objects on the chart.
member.remarks: Requires users to implement methods for interacting with IBGListener objects. The idea is that the IBGListener objects call AddBgOject and RemBgObject methods to register / deregister from the UI settings object, and the UI settings object is responsible of notifying the underlying actual object of changes in the settings, so that the object can react to the changes. The interface is implemented at least by the UiSettings class.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.IUiSettings.AddBgObject(Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.IBGListener)
member.summary: Registers the IBGListener to this object. This object is responsible to notify the listener of changes in settings.
member.param: listener to add to the listener list and to be notified of changes.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.IUiSettings.RemBgObject(Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.IBGListener)
member.summary: DeRegisters the IBGListener from this object. The listener is not to be notified of changes any longer.
member.param: listener to remove from the listener list and not to be notified of changes.
member.remarks: True if the removal succeeded. It can fail for instance if it was not on the notification list.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.UiSettings
member.summary: Base class for UI Settings. LC users see these objects as the usable objects handled in the LC. In effect these only store the settings for the actually drawed objects, that inherit IBGListener interface and cache the drawing information. This is part of a test to remove object sharing limitations from LC.

member.summary: Defines if the chart interacts with mouse at all.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.ChartOptions.m_bRaiseEventsAfterDraw
member.summary: Defines if the events raised during rendering should be emitted only at the end of the drawing (frame) or when the changes occur.
member.remarks:
If false, events are raised whenever they occur. Some properties or data may not be valid, because the control draw may not have been finished. That is the case for example when using a series data cursor, and adjusting X or Y axis scale.
If true, events are raised in sequence after the chart drawing has been finished. It ensures all data is valid for external data handling.
Moved from RenderOptionsCommon class to here. Was previously enabled on v6.something.
This only applies to chart's specific events, not events derived from ancestor CustomControl. Error event is not enqueued, but raised whenever it occurs.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.ChartOptions.ThrowChartExceptions
member.summary: Gets or sets if chart controlled errors will cause an ChartException to be thrown. This is a dependency property. Alternatively, you can use ChartError event handler to handle errors.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.ChartOptions.MouseInteraction
member.summary: Gets or sets if allow mouse interaction. Mouse hit testing with objects cause CPU overhead when the mouse is moved. This is a dependency property. If mouse interaction is not absolute necessary directly within chart and if you want to maximize the performance, set this false.
member.remarks: Major part of mouse hit test overhead is caused by series testing. Series have MouseInteraction property too, so set at least that disabled while making real-time monitoring.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.ChartOptions.RaiseEventsAfterDraw
member.summary: Defines if the events raised during rendering should be emitted only at the end of the drawing (frame) or when the changes occur.
member.remarks:
If false, events are raised whenever they occur. Some properties or data may not be valid, because the control draw may not have been finished. That is the case for example when using a series data cursor, and adjusting X or Y axis scale.
If true, events are raised in sequence after the chart drawing has been finished. It ensures all data is valid for external data handling.
This only applies to chart's specific events, not events derived from ancestor CustomControl. Error event is not enqueued, but raised whenever it occurs.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.ChartTools.ConvertDataToColorsByFixedIntervalPalette(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Windows.Media.Color[])
member.summary: Convert data values to colors, by given palette. Palette is defined by steps, consisting of value and correspoding color. E.g. 0 : Black, 50: Yellow, 100: Red. The output colors are interpolated based on their position between steps. E.g. in this example palette, data value 60 will be almost yellow, but a little bit blending with red.
member.param: Values of palette. Count must be equal to step color count.
Colors of palette. Count must be equal to step value count.
member.remarks: Use fixed interval palette steps only. E.g. 0, 25, 50, 75, 100. NOT like 0, 10, 40, 50, 80, 100.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.GridTypeSmith.Distance
member.summary:
Determine gridline positions so that each line is positioned in a point where the value is nice and event, and distance to other lines is approximately value set in GridDivSpacing.
For more information on actual positioning, see the GridDivSpacing property of AxisSmith.

member.summary: Determine gridline positions so that specific number of gridlines are placed on even distances from the center line, that is always drawn. Number of gridlines can be set using GridDivCount property. See that for more information about positionig of the gridlines.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LineAntiAliasingType.QLAA
member.remarks: In DX11 somewhat accurately defined outcome that must be met. Different drivers should produce quite similar outcome. Probably slower than ALAA as it relies on multisampling.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LineAntiAliasingType.ALAA
member.remarks: In DX11 a line AA type where driver manufacturer is somewhat free to implement the antialiasing using Alpha Blending in a way they chose as the best. Results vary quite much between different manufacturers. Should be faster than QLAA.

remarks.para: Note that size changes are handled separately and they can be changed to be handled in async way separately. Also the MoveToUIhread has similar effect to the Async options.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.ChartUpdateTypes.Sync
member.summary: Chart is updated in sync fashion on property changes. This is the fastest way to get most performance out of the chart and to minimize latency.

remarks.para: Note that with this option it is crucial that property changes / date input is grouped inside / method calls, and that the date input is done as large patches as possible, as otherwise every property change will result in new frame to be rendered, and the calls will happen on sync fashion.
This was the default and only option before LC v 8.1. To keep the old way, use this option.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.ChartUpdateTypes.Async
member.summary: Chart is updated on async fashinon. The chart will update as fast as possible after property changes, but the property changes will return as fast as possible, and chart will render new frame at some later point.
member.remarks: This might make it easier to use chart on some cases. Note that this is a new feature and might contain some problems.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.ChartUpdateTypes.LimitedFrameRate
member.summary:
Chart will limit the framerate of the udpates to value defined by .
This is similar to the Async option, but keeps prevents new frames to be rendered right after another, thus reducing framerate, but sparing system resources.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.FRLimitTypesInt
member.summary: Defines how to limit the framerate.

remarks.para: Created as part of LC7-808 and LC7-809
this is for internal usage only. User interface enum is named FrameRateLimitTypes

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.FRLimitTypesInt.Off
member.summary: No RF limitation is to be done.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.FRLimitTypesInt.AsyncTimer
member.summary: Limitation is done throuhg timer in the main thread. Actual fr is bound to be lower than the requested, but probably not by much.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.FRLimitTypesInt.Sync
member.summary: Screen updates are done synchronously. FrameRate limitation is done through waiting, so property setting might be really slow.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SeriesEventMarkerVerticalPosition.TrackSeries
member.summary: Track the series. The Y value is solved from X value. You can use this only for series implementing ITrackable interface or with FreeformPointLineSeries. Not applicable in X axis scrolling modes Scrolling, Stepping, Sweeping (monitoring modes). The resolver data is not valid for performance reasons. You should insert a marker as AtYValue in monitoring mode and convert it as TrackSeries when entering data review mode. Works only on series implementing ITrackable or with FreeformPointLineSeries.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.EnhancedAntiAliasing
member.summary: Enhanced anti-aliasing. Anti-aliasing is made in GPU shader. This is useful especially for GPUs that don't support anti-aliasing in GPU hardware. Provides better visual quality and clearness of lines than hardware anti-aliasing.

member.summary: Use only if anti-aliasing is not supported in hardware.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.EnhancedAntiAliasing.Off
member.summary: Don't use enhanced anti-aliasing. Anti-aliasing in hardware is used, if it's supported and enabled in object's settings.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.ViewAspectRatio.AutoLatitude
member.summary: Calculate aspect ratio based on view center latitude. Applicable only, when map is used. Y axis center point defines the latitude, proper XY aspect ratio is calculated based in it and X axis width is modified accordingly. This simulates the projection so that width of objects in the center of the screen are approximately of correc aspect ratio. The estimation can produce bad output on large scale and large center latitude values.

member.summary: Automatic order suggested by Arction to be used for generally best results. Value can change based on current status of different engines.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.RendererDeviceType.AutoPreferD9
member.summary: Automatic order, prefering DX9 over DX11. DX9 is currrently slightly faster than DX11 especially on WPF.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.RendererDeviceType.AutoPreferD11
member.summary: Automatic order, prefering DX11 over DX9. DX11 looks better and is more faster than DX9 on many ocations.

member.summary: Force hardware rendering for D9 device.

member.summary: Force software rendering for D9 device.

member.summary: Force hardware rendering for D11 device.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.RendererDeviceType.SoftwareOnlyD11
member.summary: Force software rendering for D11 device.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.RendererDeviceType.None
member.summary: Defines that no engine is used or not to be used. This can be used to fully disable rendering on LightningChart, and thus save (free) resources required by the rendering system. After setting this as DeviceType, it might be usefull to call GC.Collect() on some occasions.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.GridLineSource
member.summary: Selector between custom and normal gridline / ticks rendering.

member.summary: Rendering both custom and normal items.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.TextureWrapMode
member.summary: Texture wrapping. Descriptions copied from MSDN: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/bb322814(v=vs.85).aspx

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.TextureWrapMode.Wrap
member.summary: Tiles the texture at every integer junction. For example, for u values between 0 and 3, the texture is repeated three times. No mirroring is performed.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.TextureWrapMode.Mirror
member.summary: Similar to Wrap, except that the texture is flipped at every integer junction. For u values between 0 and 1, for example, the texture is addressed normally; between 1 and 2, the texture is flipped (mirrored); between 2 and 3, the texture is normal again, and so on.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.TextureWrapMode.Clamp
member.summary: Texture coordinates outside the range [0.0, 1.0] are set to the texture color at 0.0 or 1.0, respectively.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.TextureWrapMode.Border
member.summary: Texture coordinates outside the range [0.0, 1.0] are set to the border color.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.TextureWrapMode.MirrorOnce
member.summary: Similar to Mirror and Clamp. Takes the absolute value of the texture coordinate (thus, mirroring around 0), and then clamps to the maximum value. The most common usage is for volume textures, where support for the full MirrorOnce texture-addressing mode is not necessary, but the data is symmetrical around the one axis.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Cull.None
member.summary: No culling, render all triangles regardless of their normal angle to camera.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.ModKeys
member.summary: Internal modifier keys enum that combines the WPF and WinForms keys.
member.remarks: See LightninChart.GetModKeys(). In effect a copy of Wpf's ModifierKeys

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.ExtensionsClass.CalculateGradientColor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculate gradient from color to the other with amount given as pecents. Each channel is calculated separately and changed with channgel difference multiplied by the defined factor. Matches the WinForms color version but implemented differently.
member.remarks: The idea is that this would be faster than the WinForms color version. This is not verified (16/09/26)
member.param: Source color to start from as ARGB integer.
Destination color to move towards as ARGB integer.
Factor to move by, as percents. Negative and values over 100 are valid, though channel values are capped to between [0, 255].

member.summary: Checks if the given CHART reference is valid, warns (if warning enabled) if it's not, or if the m_rd is null. Reason for this is that we're using the m_chart != null in quite a lot of situation protecting the m_rd ref, and skip DD disposes if it's null. Using this we get the knowledge of where the memory freeing might have been skipped at.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Gdi.RenderDeviceGDIPlus
member.summary: GDI rendering device. Comparable to DX when thinking of RenderingEngines.
member.remarks:
Notes about clipping and stencils:
GDI does not separate clipping and stencils from eachother. There is only clipping with different paths.
Therefore there are two Paths for stencil and clipping rectangle. Clip paths are for inclusive and exclusive, which are combined, when stencil is applied.

member.param: If true (default) Disposes draw after use. The default value is true as the ChartXY used the method like this, and it's too big a job to modify it at this time.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Gdi.RenderDeviceGDIPlus.SetClipRect(System.Drawing.RectangleF)
member.summary:
Sets cliprect, meaning that this starts clipping. When setting clip the old clipping state is closed, a new state is created, and clip rect set, if an enpty rect is set, last state is removed clipping is resetted.
For SVG this works a bit differntly. On closing the clip state is not resetted.

member.name: P:Arction.RenderingEngineGDI.RenderingEngineGDI.HeadlessMode
member.summary: Defines if the engine is supposed to work in headless mode. If this is set, the engien does not try to create backbuffers visible to the screen, or update the UI components.
member.remarks:
Note that this does not directly imply or require for the engine to be in service mode, but it is useless to set this to false if in service mode, as that one takes precedense.
GDI engine does not use this information in any way.

member.name: P:Arction.RenderingEngineGDI.RenderingEngineGDI.ServiceMode
member.summary: Property one can use to get information from the engine defining if it's in service mode or not. In service mode the engine refrains from doing certain operations that are not allowed to be done when running as service. The state is automatically detected and can not (normally) be set.
member.remarks:
Note that this information is quite identical to the HeadlessMode, but takes precedence, so that no matter what the headlessmode states, if this is true, the engine is in effect at headless state. On debug interface there is a setter method for this, so tha the service mode can be tested.
GDI engine does not use this information in any way.

member.summary: Last Mouse events cursor position X coordinate as PX, rounded down from precise value.

member.summary: Last Mouse events cursor position Y coordinate as PX, rounded down from precise value.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LightningChartUltimate.m_renderingState
member.summary: Controls if the chart tries to draw anything or not. Mainly intended for stopping rendering during resizes and BeginUpdate and EndUpdate. Skipping of the rendering because of missing engine should be handled separately. Use m_renderingStateLock when using this variable. At least when setting.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LightningChartUltimate.m_renderingStateLock
member.summary: Lock for controlling concurrent access to m_renderingState variable.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LightningChartUltimate.m_bWaitingForRefresh
member.summary: Defines if the chart is waiting for refresh due to FrameRate limiting.

remarks.para: This is really similar to the m_renderingState, and might be combined to it. It's not done like that yet, because it's enforced by the exportation side extra frame renderings, and it might cause some trouble. Might be good idea to combine later though.
If this is true, DrawChartMain method will refuse to run, as it's expected that the next frame will be rendered only after this is set to false.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LightningChartUltimate.m_bExporting
member.summary: Set this, if calling export or some saving/capturing operation. Allows rendering even if m_bWaitingForRefresh is true.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LightningChartUltimate.m_deviceState
member.summary: State of the rendering engine. Note that if the state is DeviceNotCreated it does not necessarilly mean that it should be created.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LightningChartUltimate.m_bHeadlessMode
member.summary: Defines if the chart currently is in headless mode or not. This is the current state that has been reacted to. The actual requested state is in RenderingOptions, and this keeps track if we've made required modifications that needs to be made when we enter headless mode. This does not identify the reason, if it's requested headlessnes or because of we're in service.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LightningChartUltimate.m_streamOutput
member.summary:
Stream to write the rendered bitmaps to. Used mainly for headless mode rendering. More information on the OutputStream property.
Not to be disposed when chart is disposed.

member.summary: Size of the image last written to OutputStream.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LightningChartUltimate.m_lastOutputStreamFormat
member.summary: Format of the last frame written to OutputStream.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LightningChartUltimate.m_bSizePropertyMetadataOverridden
member.summary: Defines if the Width and Height properties metadata callbacks have been overridden already or not.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LightningChartUltimate.m_bPixelOffsetRequired

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LightningChartUltimate.m_pfPixelAlignmentOffset
member.summary: Last calculated pixel alignment offset. The one currently in use

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LightningChartUltimate.m_bUseGDI
member.summary: Defines if the current rendering is happening using GDI engine.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LightningChartUltimate.m_iRenderEngine
member.summary:
DX version of the current engine. Mainly uUsed to determine differnce between 9 and 11 on LC side. It should be noted that it's not ideal to make any difference on LC side, but to make the engines behave so that one needs not to know which engine is in question.
Other values have become here later. Might be good idea to change this to enumeration.
11 = DX11 9 = DX9 1 = GDI 0 = none, valid selection -1 = underfined

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LightningChartUltimate.m_deviceTypeCurrent
member.summary: Currently active rendering device. Note that this does not indicate the user selection but the actual real device that was initialized. This means that the values should never contain the "Auto*" options.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LightningChartUltimate.HandleWMDPIChangedEvent(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.Boolean@)
member.summary:
Event handler for DPI changes. Called when process is per-monitor aware and DPI changes either because the window is moved from screen to other or the user selected new DPI. Stores the new per-monitor DPI (that is not yet used anywhere) and re-positions the window (which is kind of client applications responsibility and thus might be better not to do).
User (client app) can prevent the automatic resize by use of OnDPIChanged event.
member.remarks: For more information see WM_DPICHANGED message documentation. https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/dn312083%28v=vs.85%29.aspx
member.param: Rect specifying the new suggested position and size of the window.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LightningChartUltimate.TweakDisablePresent
member.summary: Disable DirectX present calls, but let the rendering routines run otherwise

member.summary: Updates m_iClientSizeW and m_iClientSizeH variables based on given width / height (in DIPs) and current known DPI coefficients (m_fDPIXCoeff and m_fDPIYCoeff).

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LightningChartUltimate.UpdateDPI
member.summary: Updates internal DPI members from monitor data. Skips update if not required and/or should not be done. After the call m_fDPIXCoeff and m_fDPIYCoeff have valid values.
member.remarks: Delivers the information to the engine. Currently relies on GetDPICoeff that uses m_dpiSystemDefault and that does not change currently, so for now there is no reason to call this but once, or after engine changes to report it there. Later the use might change however because of the live reaction to DPI / Resolution changes, that we do not yet support properly, as we have no reliable way of ascertaining the new system dpi.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LightningChartUltimate.CaptureToByteArray(System.Int32@,System.Int32@,Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.PixelFormat@)
member.summary:
Get the last frame rendered by the chart as byte array containing just pixel data four bytes per pixel.
To get the image data with headers, like in bpm or png format, use SaveToStream method

remarks.para: Note that it is the last image rendered. If chart has yet not rendered any images with given engine, no proper image can be produced.
To get continuous stream output of the chart, use OutputStream property.

member.returns: chart's last rendered raw image as byte array. Each pixel is represented by 4 bytes in the order defined by the format parameter.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LightningChartUltimate.RecreateRenderDevice
member.remarks:
Sets m_deviceState to DeviceNotCreated on call. Sets it to DeviceAvailable only if some engine init succeeds. Should not throw exceptions, so check the m_deviceState to see if device creation succeeded. If the init was not successfull, m_re is null and a new engine creation was initiated using timer by call to the RecreateRenderDeviceWithTimer, so m_deviceState is actually DeviceNotAvailableWaitingCreationOnTimer if the engine creation fails.
m_listEngineInitResults is resetted on call, and will be filled along engine creation, so it should contain the reasons for the failure.

member.summary:
Arction internal performance anaylysis method.
Requires specialized build of LC
Do not call if you do not know what you are doing

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LightningChartUltimate.InitializeRenderingDevice(System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Tries to force the engine initialization in a synchronous fashion. Should have no use in WinForms. On WPF the engine is by default initialized only when it's put to visual tree (OnLoad event) or on device type setting if on headless mode.
This method allows user to force the rendering device initialization.
member.remarks:
The engine is re-initialized only if the current engine selection can not result in the currently active device. If it can, the engine is not re-initialized, unless forced.
The method call is async, and the engine is created on call.
member.param: Forces engine reinitilization, even if there should be no reason for it.
member.returns: true if the call resulted in valid engine that is different from the previous one.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LightningChartUltimate.HeadlessModeChanged(System.Boolean)
member.summary: call when we enter headless mode. Might change to method that is called in both directions.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LightningChartUltimate.UpdateOutputStream
member.summary:
Updates latest rendered image to the output stream.
The provided image is just the pixel color information as returned by CaptureToByteArray method. Size of the image is the charts size.
member.remarks: Currently this is synchronous, and a bit slow. We might want to do this in async manner. Possibly holding two different backends or something like that, so that user can copy the last image while next is rendered. that could be done in user space as well. maybe.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.LightningChartUltimate.OutputStream
member.summary:
Stream to write the rendered frame bitmaps to.
Defaults to null. Set the stream to this property and it will be written with ran data of the images on every frame. See remarks for the format.
This property is intended as the fastest way to capture continuous frames from the chart, especially on Headless mode.

remarks.para: The stream is a raw byte stream, with each pixel described with 4 bytes, one byte per channel. The order of the channels depends on engine and its settings. Use GetLastOutputStreamFormat and GetLastOutputStreamSize methods to find out the format and output size of the last written image. Produced image size should be of the size of the chart, in pixels.
On the contrary to the other properties of the LightningChart, set stream is NOT disposed on chart's dispose.
On the contrary to the other properties, setting this property will not cause new frame to be rendered.

member.summary: Gets total request count (per application run). License allows certain count of requests per hour. Use this value to determine whether update interval and/or automatic updates should be enabled. This is a dependency property.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Maps.WeatherBugOptions.AutoUpdateThreshold
member.summary: Gets or sets autoupdate cache tile refresh threshold. This is a dependency property. Use 0 to update always, regardless of cache tile date. Use 0.5 to update from cache, if cache tile timestamp is half of RefreshInvervalSeconds old or older. Use 1 to update from cache, if cache tile timestamp is RefreshInvervalSeconds old or older.

For X dimension, value 0 represents left coordinate of the object and 1 right coordinate. For Y dimension, value 0 represents top coordinate of the object and 1 bottom coordinate. member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.RoutedEventStorage
member.summary: Stores event / handler pairs and later registers them with a given UIElement. The reason for this class is that with XAML we do not have m_chart reference at the time routing events are registered using XAML, and we need the m_chart reference because it's the only UIElement we have and routed events are UIElement functionality.

remarks.para: Created as a separate class so that it's easier to use.
Not usable in WinForms, as it misses the whole concept of WPF routed events.

member.summary: event / handler pairs not yet registered

member.summary: Inserts new event handler to be registered for the given target event at later time.
member.param: Event to register the handler for.
Handler to register for the event.

member.summary: Registers unregistered handlers to their events using the given UIElement to do the registration.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Series3D.PointLineSeries3D.m_listPointsSorted
member.summary:
List of sorted points of the series. Either of m_pointsCompact or m_points.
Note that this is updated on drawing time, and is of exact size. On use (like mouse hit testing) size of this might be different (in either direction) from m_iActualPointCount, as this is updated on a different time and things can be run in the between. So this is the ordered points of the LAST drawn frame, not the current data.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Series3D.SurfaceSeries3DBase.SetHeightDataFromBitmap(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Drawing.Bitmap,Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.BitmapAntialiasOptions,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Create data based on bitmap file contents. Data array will have dimensions of the bitmap Width x Height. Use options to reduce resolution and smooth it if needed. Height data of is calculated for each pixel from R, G, and B sum. 0 (black) will have the minimum value, and maximum value is obtained from 3*255 (white). If bitmap has alpha value of 0, the data is set to -INF, and the value is not drawn.
member.param: Bitmap resolution decrement and smoothing options. Give null to use pure bitmap data only.
Sets NegativeInfinity when bitmap pixel has alpha = 0.
member.returns: True if data was successfully filled, else false.

member.summary: Gets or sets if draws wireframe through the filled surface. This is a dependency property. When true, wireframe is always visible from above the surface and below it. Alternatively, you may prefer setting this false and using WireframeOffset to shift the wireframe slightly up or down, making it visible only on the other side of the filled surface.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SeriesXY.HighLowSeriesBase.ScrollModePointsKeepLevel
member.summary: Gets or sets how often the draw data is cleared when using X axis scroll mode. This is a dependency property. Valid range is 1...100 1 frees the draw data and the reconstucts the draw data after every 1/10 scroll page. Use this when there's not much memory available. 100 frees the draw data and the reconstucts the draw data after every 100/10 = 10 pages. Use this when smooth scroll with high FPS is important. Reserves some extra memory.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SeriesXY.FreeformPointLineSeries
member.summary: Freeform point line series. You can define the line and points style. Add points with AddPoints method.
member.remarks:
The points don't have to be in successive order by X value. If they are used in successive order in your application, you should use PointLineSeries or SampleDataSeries instead for optimal performance. Freeform point line series causes significantly higher CPU/GPU load than other line series types, when the series point count is high.
Note that the first array is not necessarily the first point of the series, as the Points array is a circular buffer.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SeriesXY.FreeformPointLineSeries.PointCountLimit
member.summary: Gets or sets point count limit. This is a dependency property. If you add points more than limited count, first points are automatically removed. The limiter only applies if PointCountLimitEnabled is true.

member.summary: Selected how to use the individual point colors.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SeriesXY.FreeformPointLineSeries.OldestPointIndex
member.summary: Gets the index of oldest point in Points array. When PointCountLimitEnabled is true, the Points array is used as an circular point buffer. This is 0 always when PointCountLimitEnabled is false. To read Points, when OldestPointIndex is 0: Read from index 0 till PointCount-1. To read Points, when OldestPointIndex is > 0: First read from OldestPointIndex till PointCountLimit-1. Then read from index 0 till OldestPointIndex-1.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SeriesXY.PointLineSeries.ScrollModePointsKeepLevel
member.summary: Gets or sets how often the draw data is cleared when using X axis scroll mode. This is a dependency property. Valid range is 1...100 1 frees the draw data and the reconstucts the draw data after every 1/10 scroll page. Use this when there's not much memory available. 100 frees the draw data and the reconstucts the draw data after every 100/10 = 10 pages. Use this when smooth scroll with high FPS is important. Reserves some extra memory.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SeriesXY.StockSeries.CombineCoordinates(System.Collections.Generic.List{Arction.RenderingDefinitions.StockSeriesPointCoordinates[]},System.Single)
member.summary:
Combines two first arrays of the input list, shifting the X coordinates of the first array by fScrollModeOldShiftX using ShiftXData method.
If input list listArray has one item, it is returned _unshifted_. Otherwise ShiftXDate method is used to shift the first array and the second array is copied to the output array as it is. Other arrays of the input list are ignored.
The input list is cleared.
member.param: List of max 2 arrays, that are combined so that first one is shifted by the given amount. The input list is cleared.
Amount to shift (add to x values) of the first array of the input list.
member.returns: Null for null input and if more than one arrays on list but no points. Original first array if list count is one Otherwise the putput array contains first arra shifted with fScrollModeOldShiftX and copy of the second array.

member.summary: True if optimal pure device mode is supported.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.RenderDeviceInfo.FastVertexFormat
member.summary: True if your graphics adapter supports fast vertex format. Fast vertices are not available for old graphics adapters. If false, the rendering performance is not optimal, since slower vertex formats must be used. Getting a new graphics adapter is strongly recommended, ensure it is at least DirectX 10 level, for best performance.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.RenderDeviceInfo.HardwareVertexProcessing
member.summary: True if your graphics adapter supports vertex processing in hardware (GPU). If false, the vertex calculation has to be done in software (computer CPU), and the performance is not optimal.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.RenderDeviceInfo.ShaderModel3
member.summary: True if shader model 3 is supported. Both vertex and pixel shaders are format 3 or greater.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.RenderDeviceInfo.IndexBuffers32Bit
member.summary: True if 32-bit index buffers are supported. If only 16-index buffers are supported, returns false. In this case the 3D surfaces may be limited into smaller sizes.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.RenderDeviceInfo.TexturesSizesNonPowerOf2
member.summary: Limited support for textures which size is not power of two.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.RenderDeviceInfo.D2Dv11Supported
member.summary: True if D2D v1.1 is supported, false if not. The v1.1 is required for HW text rendering on DX11. On DX9 this is always false.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.RenderDeviceInfo.D3DImageUsed
member.summary: True if D3DImage was used in drawing of the last frame. Always false on WinForms

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.RenderDeviceInfo.DpiAware
member.summary: True if sofware is DPI aware

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.RenderDeviceInfo.Memory
member.summary: Memory on the graphics card (if information is available).

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.MouseHitInfo3D.Button

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.RenderingSettings
member.summary:
Rendering settings, that can be given as chart constructor parameter. Speeds up creating of the chart, if non-default values are given, preventing the chart rendering engine to be re-created several times.
Note that the values are only read once after the chart is created, and changing them later has no effect. This object can also be shared between multiple charts.

remarks.para: This might be changed to structure in the future.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.RenderingSettings.AntiAliasLevel
member.summary: Anti-aliasing factor. 1 = no anti-aliasing. The larger the value, the smoother the image will be, but at steep cost of performance on some display adapters. Only objects having AntiAlias property will be anti-aliased, if it's set to 'Normal'

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.RenderingSettings.WaitforVSync
member.summary: Wait for next refresh, V-Sync. If the computer is fast enough, disabling this can give higher refresh rate than the screen refresh rate is. By disabling this, rendering does not wait next screen refresh turn. Enabling this may improve performance especially in slow computers.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.RenderingSettings.D2DEnabled
member.summary: Temporary debug setting for disabling D2D system and text rendering on DX11.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.RenderingSettings.ChartErrorDelegate
member.summary:
Delegate to register to the ChartError event. Initialized this way the chart error event is launched even before the object has been fully constructed.
Intended primarilly as debug measure for cases when LC crashes on constructor and we need more information on why it happens.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.RenderingSettings.DeviceType
member.summary: Default rendering device engine to use. Defaults to Auto.l

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.RenderingSettings.HeadlessMode
member.summary: Identifies that we do not actually have a graphical interface. This is true for instance for services or console applications. This can also be used if the chart is intended to run on background without an actual interface.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.RenderingSettings.#ctor
member.summary: Constructor for Form designer list editor

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgElement
member.summary:
The base class for SVG elements. It represents some part of an SVG document, either an element (rect, circle etc) or a text item. Duties include:
Maintains a list of child elements and a list of attributes.
Writes itself and its children to an Xml document.
Reads itself and its children from an Xml document.

member.summary: Given an XML document and a parent node, write out this node and its descendants as XmlElements.
member.param: A node, or null if this element is to be the root element

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgElement.WriteSVGString(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Get a string that contains a complete SVG document. XML version, DOCTYPE etc are included.
member.param: Should usually be set true. Causes the XML output to be optimized so that long attributes like styles and transformations are represented with entities.

member.summary: Static methods to produce/write/copy Svg documents reside in this class.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgFactory.LoadFromXML(System.Xml.XmlDocument,System.Xml.XmlElement)
member.summary: Given an xml document and (optionally) a particular element to start from, read the xml nodes and construct a tree of objects. Xml tags that do not correspond to a particular class will be represented by an . This means that literally any XML input can be read in and written out, even if it has nothing to do with Svg. More usefully, it means that new and unsupported tags and attributes will be represented in the SvgElement tree and written out correctly even if SvgNet does not understand them.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgFactory.CompressXML(System.Xml.XmlDocument,System.Xml.XmlElement)
member.summary:
Helper function to compress long xml attributes into entities.
This would work on any XML, it is not SVG specific, so it should eventually be in some 'xml tools' class.
member.returns: A string of entities which can be inserted into the DOCTYPE when the document is written.

member.summary: Create a complete deep copy of the given tree of SvgElement objects. A new set of elements is created, and if the attributes are cloneable they are deep-copied too. Since strings and all SvgType classes are cloneable, the new tree is independant of the old.

member.summary: This is an SvgElement that can have a CSS style and an SVG transformation list. It contains special properties to make reading and setting the style and the transformation easier. All SVG elements that actually represent visual entities or groups of entities are SvgStyledTransformedElements.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.IGraphics
member.summary:
An interface that contains exactly the same methods as the GDI+ Graphics object. If your drawing routines draw to an IGraphics interface, then you can supply either a GdiGraphics object to render to the screen, or an object to render to an SVG file.
It's a pity that Graphics is a sealed class. Otherwise there'd be no need to have this interface or the class; we could simply derive a class from Graphics to do SVG output.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.GdiGraphics
member.summary: An IGraphics implementation that simply passes every call through to a GDI+ Graphics object.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGdiNotImpl
member.summary: Exception thrown when a GDI+ operation is attempted on an IGraphics implementor that does not support the operation. For instance, SvgGraphics does not support any of the MeasureString methods.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics
member.summary:
This is an IGraphics implementor that builds up an SVG scene. Use it like a regular Graphics object, and call WriteXMLString to output SVG. In this way, whatever you would normally draw becomes available as an SVG document.
SvgGraphics has to do quite a lot of work to convert GDI instructions to SVG equivalents. Some things are approximated and slight differences will be noticed. Also, in several places GDI+ does not do what it is supposed to (e.g. arcs of non-circular ellipses, truncating bitmaps). In these cases SvgGraphics does do the right thing, so the result will be different.
Some GDI instructions such as MeasureString are meaningless in SVG, usually because there is no physical display device to refer to. When such a method is called an exception is thrown.
Many parameters used by GDI have no SVG equivalent -- for instance, GDI allows some fine control over how font hints are used. This detailed information is thrown away.
Some aspects of GDI that can be implemented in SVG are not. The most important omission is that only solid brushes are supported.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.WriteSVGString
member.summary: Get a string containing an SVG document. The very heart of SvgGdi. It calls WriteSVGString on the at the root of this SvgGraphics and returns the resulting string.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.DrawString(System.String,System.Drawing.Font,System.Drawing.Brush,System.Drawing.PointF)
member.summary:
Implemented.
In general, DrawString functions work, but it is impossible to guarantee that an SVG renderer will have a certain font and draw it in the same way as GDI+.
SVG does not do word wrapping and SvgGdi does not emulate it yet (although clipping is working). The plan is to wait till SVG 1.2 becomes available, since 1.2 contains text wrapping/flowing attributes.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.DrawImage(System.Drawing.Image,System.Drawing.PointF)
member.summary:
Implemented. The DrawImage group of functions emulate drawing a bitmap by creating many SVG rect elements. This is quite effective but can lead to a very big SVG file. Alpha and stretching are handled correctly. No antialiasing is done.
The GDI+ documentation suggests that the 'Unscaled' functions should truncate the image. GDI+ does not actually do this, but SvgGraphics does.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.HandleBrush(System.Drawing.Brush)
member.summary:
When a GDI instruction with a brush parameter is called, there can be a lot we have to do to emulate the brush. The aim is to return a style that represents the brush.
Solid brush is very easy.
Linear grad brush: we ignore the blend curve and the transformation (and therefore the rotation parameter if any) Hatch brush:
Other types of brushes are too hard to emulate and are rendered pink.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.MatrixStack
member.summary:
This class is needed because GDI+ does not maintain a proper scene graph; rather it maintains a single transformation matrix which is applied to each new object. The matrix is saved and reloaded when 'begincontainer' and 'endcontainer' are called. SvgGraphics has to emulate this behaviour.
This matrix stack caches it's 'result' (ie. the current transformation, the product of all matrices). The result is recalculated when necessary.

The SVG text element is unusual in that it expects actual XML text nodes below it, rather than consisting only of attributes and child elements (other elements like this are title, desc, and tspan). SvgTextElement therefore has to be serialized to XML slightly differently.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgStyle.#ctor(System.Drawing.Pen)
member.summary: Creates a style from a GDI+ pen object. Most properties of the pen are implemented, but GDI+ allows fine control over line-capping which has no equivalent in SVG.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgStyle.#ctor(System.Drawing.SolidBrush)
member.summary: Creates a style based on a GDI brush object. Only works for solid brushes; pattern brushes are not yet emulated.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgStyle.#ctor(System.Drawing.Font)
member.summary: Creates a style based on a GDI+ font object. GDI+ allows many subtle specifications which have no SVG equivalent.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgStyle.Set(System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Sets a style. The key must be a string but the value can be anything (e.g. SvgColor). If and when the element that owns this style is written out to XML, ToString will be called on the value.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgStyle.Get(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the value for a given key.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgStyle.FromString(System.String)
member.summary: Parses a CSS string representation as used in SVG.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgStyle.ToString
member.summary: Outputs a CSS string representation as used in SVG.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgStyle.op_Addition(Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgStyle,Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgStyle)
member.summary: Adds two SvgStyles together, resulting in a new object that contains all the attributes of both styles. Attributes are copied deeply, i.e. cloned if they are ICloneable.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgStyle.Keys
member.summary: A basic way to enumerate the styles.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgStyle.Item(System.String)
member.summary: A quick way to get and set style elements.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgTransform
member.summary: Represents a single element in an SVG transformation list. The transformation is represented internally as a GDI+ Matrix object.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgTransform.FromString(System.String)
member.summary: Parse a transformation according to the SVG standard. This is complex enough that it makes me wish it was worth using a real parser, but antlr is so unwieldy.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgTransform.ToString
member.summary: Currently, we always output as matrix() no matter how the transform was specified.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgTransformList
member.summary: Represents an SVG transform-list, as specified in section 7.6 of the SVG 1.1 standard.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgTransformList.FromString(System.String)
member.summary: Parse a string containing a whitespace-separated list of transformations as per the SVG standard

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgLengthType
member.summary: The various units in which an SvgLength can be specified.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgAngleType
member.summary: The units in which an SvgAngle can be specified

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgPathSegType
member.summary: The various different types of segment that make up an SVG path, as listed in the SVG Path grammar.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgNumber
member.summary: A number, as specified in the SVG standard. It is stored as a float.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgNumber.FromString(System.String)
member.summary: float.Parse is used to parse the string. float.Parse does not follow the exact rules of the SVG spec.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgNumber.ToString
member.summary: float.ToString is used to output a string. This is true for all numbers in SvgNet.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgLength
member.summary: A length or coordinate component (in SVG 1.1 the specification says they are the same)

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgAngle
member.summary: An angle, as found here and there throughout the SVG spec

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgColor
member.summary: A color, as found in CSS2 and used in SVG. As well as a GDI Color object, SvgColor stores the string it was initialized from, so that when a color specified as 'black' is written out, it will be written 'black' rather than '#000000'

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgColor.FromString(System.String)
member.summary: As well as parsing the four types of CSS color descriptor (rgb, #xxxxxx, color name, and system color name), the FromString of this type stores the original string

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgColor.ToString
member.summary: If the SvgColor was constructed from a string, use that string; otherwise use rgb() form

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.PathSeg
member.summary: A segment in an Svg path. This is not a real SVG type; it is not in the SVG spec. It is provided for making paths easier to specify and parse.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgPath
member.summary: A path, composed of segments, as described in the SVG 1.1 spec section 8.3

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgPath.FromString(System.String)
member.summary: The parsing of the path is not completely perfect yet. You can only have one space between path elements.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgPoints
member.summary: A list of points, as specified in the SVG 1.1 spec section 9.8. Only used in polygon and polyline elements.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgPoints.#ctor(System.Single[])
member.summary: The array must have an even length

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgPoints.FromString(System.String)
member.summary: The standard boils down to a list of numbers in any format separated by any amount of wsp and commas; in other words it looks the same as a SvgNumList

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgNumList
member.summary: A number list, as used in the SVG spec for e.g. the value of a viewBox attribute. Basically a list of numbers in any format separated by whitespace and commas.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgUriReference
member.summary: Represents a URI reference within a style. Local uri references are generally strings of the form url(#elementID). This class should not be confused with which represents the xlink:* properties of, for example, an a element.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgXRef
member.summary: Represents a URI reference. Unlike most svg types, uri references are represented by more than one attribute of an element. This means special measures are required to get and set uri references.

Notification to parent that the settings defining the draw data related to sender and/or relayer has been modified and the drawdata needs to be recalculated/updated/redefined/freed.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.MathRoutines.LinearFitSolveFactors(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Calculate linear fit from given points. Makes best fit with Least Square regression method. A line equation is y = k*x + b, that is, y = gradient * x + coefficient
member.param: Coefficient, Y value of intersection where X = 0
member.remarks: X values array lenght must be equal to Y values array length

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.MathRoutines.LinearRegression(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Calculate linear line fit for given points
member.param: X values that are used to calculate the factors. This is the point set where the regression line is fitted to.
Y values that are used to calculate the factors. Length must be equal to xInFactorization length.
X values whose Y values are to be solved, using the factors
member.returns: Fitted Y values, the length equals to xValuesToFit length. Returns null if failed.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.MathRoutines.PolynomialRegression(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculate polymial line fit. Calculates polynomial factors, and uses these factors to solve Y values based on given X value array.
member.param: X values that are used to calculate the factors. This is the point set where the regression line is fitted to.
Y values that are used to calculate the factors. Length must be equal to xInFactorization length.
X values whose Y values are to be solved, using the factors
Order of polynomial. Usually more than 3 shouldn't be used
member.returns: Fitted Y values, the length equals to xValuesToFit length. Returns null if failed.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.MathRoutines.PolynomialRegression(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Double[]@)
member.summary: Calculate polymial line fit. Calculates polynomial factors, and uses these factors to solve Y values based on given X value array.
member.param: X values that are used to calculate the factors. This is the point set where the regression line is fitted to.
Y values that are used to calculate the factors. Length must be equal to xInFactorization length.
X values whose Y values are to be solved, using the factors
Order of polynomial. Usually more than 3 shouldn't be used
Polynomial result factors, length = order+1. For example, when having order 2, you can plot line with equation: Y = factors[0] + factors[1]*X + factors[2]*X^2
member.returns: Fitted Y values, the length equals to xValuesToFit length. Returns null if failed.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.MathRoutines.FirstRectLineIntersection(Arction.RenderingDefinitions.PointFloat[],Arction.RenderingDefinitions.PointFloat,Arction.RenderingDefinitions.PointFloat,Arction.RenderingDefinitions.PointFloat@,System.Int32[]@)
member.summary: Identical to FirstLinesetIntersections method, but forces 4 corners, handles the last to first coord for second time.

member.summary: Finds intersections (0..2) between circle and an axis aligned line _segment_. The found points are added to the list. Order of the endpoints does not matter.
member.remarks: Algorithm could easilly have bool property that would allow reporting of actual line, not line segment intersection. The detection algorighm is quite stupid, sorry for that.

member.summary: Calculates intersection point of two lines. Line 1: goes through A1 and A2 Line 2: goes through B1 and B2

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.D2DEnabled
member.summary: Determines if the D2D system is used or not. Text rendering does not work on DX11 without D2D. This is intended only as Debug measure at this time, and the property will be removed later.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.FrameRateLimitUI
member.summary: Internal property for the UI side value for RF limit.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.AntiAliasLevel
member.summary: Gets or sets anti-aliasing factor. 1 = no anti-aliasing. This is a dependency property. The larger the value, the smoother the image will be, but at steep cost of performance on some display adapters. Only objects having AntiAlias property will be anti-aliased, if it's set to 'Normal'
member.remarks: Note that the value will be limited to a highest value the active engine supports and updated on engine intialization.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.LineAAType2D
member.summary: Anti-aliasing type of single pixel width anti-aliased lines for 2D Views. Applicaple only on DX11 and when AntiAliasLevel is above 1. Lines thicker than 1 px are rendered using triangles, and use triangle drawing AA system. ALAA option produces generally best looking line and is faster than QLAA. There is some problems with ALAA with Warp though.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.LineAAType3D
member.summary: Anti-aliasing type of single pixel width anti-aliased lines for 3D Views. Applicaple only on DX11 and when AntiAliasLevel is above 1. Lines thicker than 1 px are rendered using triangles, and use triangle drawing AA system. ALAA option produces generally best looking line and is faster than QLAA. There is some problems with ALAA with Warp though.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.LineOffset
member.summary: Debug Line offset of the DX11 line drawing. LightningChart internally uses coordinate system where the coordinate points to the center of the pixel. Meaning that screen coordinate (0,0) is at the center of the top-left pixel. In DX9 this is the same. In DX11 the point (0,0) is at the top-left corner of the top-left pixel, and the center of the pixel is at point (0.5, 0.5). The points are moved by this offset in DX11 engine, so that the chart can use the same coordinate system with all engines. The default value of (0.5, 0.5) is the "correct" one, but it can be modified by this property.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.WaitForVSync
member.summary: Gets or sets if wait for next refresh, V-Sync. This is a dependency property. If the computer is fast enough, disabling this can give higher refresh rate than the screen refresh rate is. By disabling this, rendering does not wait next screen refresh turn.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.FontsQuality
member.summary: Gets or sets fonts rendering quality. This is a dependency property.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.InvokeRenderingInUIThread
member.summary: Gets or sets if use thread safe updates to force the control draw itself though Invoke. This is a dependency property. Enabling this may cause slower updates, and should not be used in applications running without auxliary threads updating the chart data or properties. Alternatively, you can use Invoke method of your parent form or control. You should always update the chart data from by Invoking in application side.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.UpdateOnResize
member.summary: Gets or sets if update chart always when resizing control. This is a dependency property.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.UpdateOnResizeTimeInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets chart update interval (ms) after resizing ends, if UpdateAlwaysOnResize is false. This is a dependency property.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.BindableCharting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.RemoteDesktopVendorId
member.summary: Gets or sets RemoteDeskTop graphics card id. This is a dependency property.
member.remarks: If remote desktop does not seem to work, set this value to GPU id.
